awd_titl_txt: Regional Cybersecurity/Cyberinfrastructure Workshop Targeting Minority Serving Institutions: Low-Cost/High-Impact Cyberdefense and Cyberinfrastructure Resources
awd_abstract_narration:
The CyberRISK (Regional Information Security Knowledge-sharing) workshop brings together twenty Minority-Serving Institutions (MSIs) with diverse characteristics and academic missions, but with a shared need for training, resources, and peer networking on  Because cybersecurity postures arise from policy and technical designs, attending institutions bring two participants: one policy lead (CIO or senior leader with policy-setting authority) and one technical lead (security or networking resource responsible for security protections). Workshop programs follow policy and technical tracks, emphasizing their coordination for effectiveness and coherence.  Pre-workshop surveys shape workshop content so it is relevant for the diverse institutional circumstances, priorities, and levels of cybersecurity maturity.

National and regional cyber experts, network operators, and research university peers participate to broaden and diversify insight into best practices and relevant service offerings, and to promote interaction around campus cyberinfrastructure, science use cases, and regional / national cyberinfrastructure resources.

This workshop's intellectual merit stems from information exchanged at the event, which leads to new ideas, relationships and collaborations among the diverse participants: colleges and universities, regional and national cyber experts, and relevant consortia.  Evaluative instruments employed before, during, and after the event shed light on changes and actions arising from the workshop that improve participants' cybersecurity postures.  Broader impact of this workshop begins with the dissemination of workshop materials, presentations, and plans that are publicly available for adaptation and reuse; it extends further by providing a framework and model for future regional workshops, with the results of evaluative instruments available to guide improvements of those workshops.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the efforts of a team from North Carolina Central University, MCNC, and Duke University to develop and deliver two multi-day workshops, one each in 2019 and 2021. The workshops provided cybersecurity programming and professional development to Information Technology (IT) leadership and technical personnel from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) and other Minority Serving Institutions (MSIs) in the region (in 2019) and beyond (in 2021).

The Inaugural CyberRISK workshop was held in person in Durham, NC in July 2019 and engaged 15 MSI colleges and universities with 28 individual registrants from those institutions and spanning North Carolina, South Carolina, and Virginia in the two-day workshop. A second three-part online CyberRISK workshop was delivered via Zoom to remote participants in July 2021. As an online conference that was unencumbered by travel constraints, the 2021 workshop included registrants from Virginia, Alabama, Louisiana, Texas, South Carolina, North Carolina, and New Mexico. A total of 10 schools participated and 13 individuals from those institutions.

The inaugural (2019) in-person workshop provided clarity to financial support that cybersecurity requires and did so directly to Chief Information Officer- and Chief Information Security Officer-level participant. The participants recognized the close relationship of the designs of cybersecurity and cyberinfrastructure and because the workshop design brought together IT administrative leadership and IT professional talents, these relationships of cybersecurity and cyberinfrastructure more easily became evident to participants. That inaugural workshop also improved dissemination of best practices in cybersecurity, especially to institutions that are often under-resourced and have fewer opportunities for staff development. Participants were introduced to programs offered by Internet2, EDUCAUSE and REN-ISAC and learned about cybersecurity assistance provide by the FBI. Participants were also introduced to STINGAR, an NSF-funded (NSF-1815691, NSF-1840034) security platform with an opensource implementation that enables real-time threat identification and sharing threat intelligence. Four participants in the 2019 CyberRISK workshop have adopted STINGAR as part of their ongoing cybersecurity program. 

Quantitative survey feedback from the inaugural workshop showed that it met all four goals identified for the project:

1. Participation from at least 75 percent of invited HBCUs/MSIs in NC, SC, and VA, within a 220-mile radius.

2. Educating participants in the necessity of strong cybersecurity programs and introducing effective tools sourced from within the higher ed community and beyond, including using the industry-standard CIS Top 20 Controls security framework with participants.

3. Promoting interactions between personnel from large research universities and MSIs.

4. Fostering connections between campus cyberinfrastructure, science driven applications, and regional and national cyberinfrastructure resources.

The subsequent (2021) online workshop furthered the dissemination of best practices in cybersecurity and broadened participation through the inclusion of HBCUs and other MSIs beyond the NC-SC-VA region. During this online workshop, we explored the interdependencies between cyber security, cyber risk, and cyber infrastructure, and culminating in the development of cyber risk assessments, establishment of cybersecurity priorities, and exploration of cyberinfrastructure (CI) planning. Templates from existing university CI plans were employed as a means of connecting CI planning to the relevance of a cybersecurity plan and participants explored the steps to create their own cybersecurity action plan.  

Collectively, the workshops facilitated interactive forums for participants and national groups including Internet2, EDUCAUSE and REN-ISAC. The result of this networking enabled participants to discuss cybersecurity with peers and industry leaders, as well as exposed them to shared services in the cybersecurity domain both nationally and regionally. For example, cybersecurity programs provided through MCNC's growing portfolio of professional services in cybersecurity protection and cyber risk assessment.

The collaboration among MSI engendered through this project has built trust among participating institutions, leading to a willingness to continue the collaboration with one another and in pursuit of other collaborative programs and shared services. The CyberRISK program serves as a model that can be replicated, and which will be pursued in coordination with the NSF-funded Minority Serving - Cyberinfrastructure Consortium program, MS-CC (OAC 2137123). The participants at the inaugural CyberRISK workshop were exposed to the emerging MS-CC program and some became active in the program through the connections made at that workshop.

Workshop materials have been posted on a publicly accessible CyberRISK project website (sites.duke.edu/cyberrisk) for use by participating institutions and others to inform their ongoing cybersecurity and cyberinfrastructure planning efforts. They are posted under a CC-BY-SA license, unless otherwise noted.
